# Wanted features

## Engine features

- ECS architecture
- LittleJS integration for rendering and physics
- Modding support
- Procedural generation
- Content loadable from JSON files (or another format if better suited to our needs). Would help the modding support.
- Game API for modders
- Interconnected systems that work together seamlessly
- Save and load functionality

## Misc. features

- Achievements and challenges for replayability
- Status effects and conditions
- Environmental interactions and hazards

## Regular roguelike features

Most regular features found in popular roguelikes, including but not limited to:

- Complex character progression: Players can develop their characters through skills, attributes, and equipment.
- Resource management: Players must manage limited resources such as health, mana, food, and inventory space.
- Random events and encounters: Unpredictable events and enemy encounters add variety and challenge.
- A main quest and many sidequests
- Skills and abilities with cooldowns or limited uses
- Spells and magic systems
- Inventory management and item identification: items are mostly unidentified when picked up, and must be identified via scrolls, automatic appraising, by NPC services, etc., before their true properties are known
- Items can be blessed, improving their stats and eventually providing unique effects
- Tactical combat with positioning, flanking, cover, line of sight, etc.
- Dungeon crawling
- Worldmap with various locations to visit
- z-levels in dungeons (multiple floors)
- Tactical combat with positioning, flanking, cover, line of sight, etc.
- Variety of enemy types with unique behaviors and abilities
- Loot and treasure hunting, including rare and unique items, dropped by enemies or bosses, or discovered in hidden locations or received as quest/God rewards
- Item materials affecting stats and properties: iron, steel, silver, mithril, wood, leather, cloth, etc.
- Feature complete roguelike ready for release having all core mechanics and features implemented, polished, and tested, and the best features of the most popular and interesting roguelikes
- Non-linear exploration with multiple paths and secrets
- Skill progression through use, allowing players to improve skills by practicing them

## Less common, misc., or uncommon roguelike features

- Deep procedural generation of worlds, locations, and items
- Complex character development
- Rich lore and storytelling through environmental details
- Factions and reputation systems affecting gameplay
- Turn-based tactical combat
- Heavy use of ECS
- Integration of traditional roguelike elements with modern gameplay features
- Extensive use of random events and encounters
- Procedurally generated quests and missions
- Extensive item variety with unique properties
- Skill-based progression system
- Extensive crafting system
- Many item modifiers
- Affinity system with NPCs towards the player
- Non-permadeath mode option
- Some unique, named, non-procedurally generated NPCs
- Skill and stats XP and Potential system
- Many service type NPCs, mostly but not limited to merchants, like:
  - Mages to sell magic scrolls and rods, and to identify items and artifacts for a fee
  - Goods shopkeepers
  - Furniture shopkeepers
  - Bankers
  - Secretaries
  - Healers
  - Blacksmiths
  - etc.
- Explorable dungeons with multiple levels, different types, a boss to beat, and good loot as a reward
- Large variety of skills and feats
- Deep character customization with classes, talents, and abilities
- Turn-based tactical combat with strategic depth
- Extensive item variety with unique properties
- Skill-based progression system
- Many abilities/skills to use, and improve at level ups
- Impressive character builds possibilities
- Dynamic world events affecting gameplay
- Impressive quantity of interconnected stats and attributes with modifiers
- Classes are very different from each other and provide a unique experience each, and races are interesting
- Many equipables

## Quality of life features

- Integration of traditional roguelike elements with modern gameplay features
- Support for both keyboard and mouse controls
- Accessibility options for different player needs
- Player can establish home bases, populate it with residents, improve the bases rank to gain more income, improve their tourism value to attract more guests that produce income, etc.
- Auto-filled journal

## Features to research

## Features to possibly implement

- Encyclopedia-like dialog system (although can be improved)?

## Features from other genres

- Expansive, impressively large procedurally generated world
- Open world exploration with freedom to go anywhere
- Diverse towns and dungeons to explore
- Variety of unusual skills like different languages that can be learned: dragon language, daedric language, etc., allowing completely optional and missable interactions with special NPCs and quests
- Spell crafting system allowing players to create custom spells
- Joinable guilds, providing various advantages and focused on a singular concept (Fighter's Guild, Mage's Guild, Thieves' Guild, etc.) with player rank progression through missions, and unique rewards
- In-depth NPC interactions with unique dialogue and personalities
- Alchemy system for creating potions from ingredients found in the world
- Day-night cycle and dynamic weather system affecting gameplay and NPC behavior
- NPC schedules, with characters following daily routines
- Player can catch afflictions like Lycanthropy and Vampirism, greatly affecting the gameplay, and providing advantages and drawbacks
- Character customization through clan selection and ability choices
- Augmentation system allowing for character customization and diverse playstyles
- Deep RPG elements with character stats, skills, and inventory management
- Dialogue options influenced by character stats and augmentations
- Player freedom to shape their character's identity and role in the world

## Most important features (outside of regular features)

## Conclusions

Basically, implement all the features listed here that are not regular roguelike features, and all the regular roguelike features that are not already planned in the roadmap. Mix the best of both lists to create an impressive roguelike game with a unique identity. Focus on features that enhance player engagement, replayability, and immersion, while ensuring a solid foundation of core roguelike mechanics. Take heavy inspiration from the best roguelikes out there, and aim to create a game that stands out in the genre with its unique features and gameplay elements.
